NdArray.description: This object represents a numpy nd-array

dtype.description: The desired data-type for the array.  If not given, then the type will be determined as the minimum type required to hold the objects in the sequence.

copy.description: If true (default), then the object is copied.  Otherwise, a copy will only be made if __array__ returns a copy, if obj is a nested sequence, or if a copy is needed to satisfy any of the other requirements(`dtype`, `order`, etc.).

order.description: Specify the memory layout of the array. If object is not an array, the newly created array will be in C order (row major) unless 'F' is specified, in which case it will be in Fortran order (column major). If object is an array the following holds.

subok.description: If True, then sub-classes will be passed-through, otherwise the returned array will be forced to be a base-class array (default).

ndmin.description: Specifies the minimum number of dimensions that the resulting array should have.  Ones will be pre-pended to the shape as needed to meet this requirement.

like.description: Reference object to allow the creation of arrays which are not NumPy arrays. If an array-like passed in as ``like`` supports the ``__array_function__`` protocol, the result will be defined by it. In this case, it ensures the creation of an array object compatible with that passed in via this argument.

Index.description: This object represents a serie for Pandas

Series.description: This object represents series for Pandas

dtype.description: dtype object of the underlying data.

Dataframe.description: Two-dimensional size-mutable, potentially heterogeneous tabular data structure with labeled axes (rows and columns).

i18n.description: This is a mixin for classes that require multlingual support

languageCode.$comment: enumeration ordered by pondering each 1st language of a country with its population, worldwide

UID.description: The eventâ€™s unique id. This id should be globally unique so you should add an @DOMAIN_NAME to your id.

CLASS.description: The event class (e.g. PUBLIC, PRIVATE, CONFIDENTIAL)

GEO.description: The latitude and longitude of the event. The value returned by this property should be a two-tuple containing the latitude and longitude as float values. semicolon. Ex: (37.386013, -122.082932)

ORGANIZER.description: The event organizer. Expected to be a vCalAddress object. See iCalendar documentation or tests to know how to build them.

STATUS.description: The status of an event. Can be CONFIRMED, CANCELLED or TENTATIVE.

TRANSP.description: The event transparency. Defines whether the event shows up in busy searches. (e.g. OPAQUE, TRANSPARENT)

ATTENDEE.description: The event attendees. Expected to be a list of vCalAddress objects. See iCalendar documentation or tests to know how to build them.

EXDATE.description: The dates/times for exceptions of a recurring event. See iCalendar documentation or tests to know how to build them.

RDATE.description: The recurring dates/times for a repeating event. See iCalendar documentation or tests to know how to build them.

RRULE.description: The recurrence rule for repeating events. See iCalendar documentation or tests to know how to build them.

VALARM.description: Alarms for the event, must be a list of Alarm objects. See iCalendar documentation or tests to know how to build them.

Calendar.description: This is the base object for an iCalendar file.

METHOD.description: The calendar method such as meeting requests.

ContentType.description: This represents associates a typed content to a db model symbol.

Permission.description:
The permissions system provides a way to assign permissions to specific users and groups of users.

The permission system is used by the Django admin site, but may also be useful in your own code. The Django admin site uses permissions as follows:
    - The "add" permission limits the user's ability to view the "add" form
      and add an object.
    - The "change" permission limits a user's ability to view the change
      list, view the "change" form and change an object.
    - The "delete" permission limits the ability to delete an object.
    - The "view" permission limits the ability to view an object.

Permissions are set globally per type of object, not per specific object instance. It is possible to say "Mary may change news stories," but it's not currently possible to say "Mary may change news stories, but only the ones she created herself" or "Mary may only change news stories that have a certain status or publication date."
The permissions listed above are automatically created for each model.

Group.description:
Groups are a generic way of categorizing users to apply permissions, or some other label, to those users.
A user can belong to any number of groups. A user in a group automatically has all the permissions granted to that group. For example, if the group 'Site editors' has the permission can_edit_home_page, any user in that group will have that permission.

User.description: This objects represents a fully featured User model with admin-compliant permissions.

username.description: Unique User name, usually email address

BankAccount.description: This objects represents a bank account.

contentSizeHuman.description: Content size in human readable units.

Address.description: This object represents an address following the convention of http://microformats.org/wiki/hcard

Card.description: This object represent a person, a company, an organization, or a place

Manufacturer.description: This objects represents a product manufacturer.

Model.description: This objects represents an app model.

Fixture.description: This objects represents an app fixture.

View.description: This objects represents an app view.

Namespace.description: This objects represents an app namespace.

Pair.description: This objects represents a conversational pair.

Chatbot.description: This objects represents a conversational NLTK chatbot

reflections.description: Mapping between first and second person expressions
